title: Tech & Social Impact - Power of Volunteering
abstract:
In this talk, I’ll discuss how developers can harness the power of volunteering in order to develop their skills, positively influence others and maintain a helpful work/life balance whilst incorporating volunteering into their schedule.

I want the audience to understand that volunteering makes the technology industry accessible and why everyone should volunteer at some point in their tech journey. I want the audience to feel empowered and encouraged to start volunteering and that even volunteering a small amount of their time can make a big impact on others.

speakers.name: Bea
speakers.bio: Bea is a frontend engineer, who transitioned into technology with the help of coding communities. She is passionate about helping others and aspires to mentor others in the future

title: Docs For Equity - Teaching Our Way Out Of Impostor Syndrome
abstract:
Using the principles of culturally responsive teaching to shape documentation can help create better docs for EVERYONE, and especially for marginalized communities. Impostor syndrome is a cover for inequity, and we have tools to deal with it: 
1. Reflecting on your own cultural lens 
2. Recognizing and redressing bias in the system
3. Communicating in linguistically and culturally responsive ways
4. Demonstrating respect for diversity
5. Emphasizing real-world context

I'll include some ideas for how to pitch deeper investment in docs to your team and management.

speakers.name: Julia Seidman
speakers.bio: Julia is a believer in the careen, rather than the career. After studying anthropology and writing a senior thesis on the ethics of museum collections of human skeletal remains, she took the job she could get: fundraising for a hospital. From there, she became a financial analyst and employee educator for 401k plans. Then, after getting her Master's in education, she taught high school English and ESL for most of a decade. Now, she is a technical content marketing consultant and developer.

title: Demystifying Web Accessibility
abstract:
Accessibility is a decisive tool to make the internet a more inclusive place, it is absolutely crucial and despite the popular belief that only a small user group is affected, it benefits every single one of us. The reality doesn’t yet reflect that, though - accessibility often just seems like an afterthought. 
I will show the benefits of implementing accessibility and eliminate some of the prejudices. ​I want the audience to take away the fact that it's rather easy to get started, that a little bit is better than nothing and give them helpful tools to put their motivation into action.

speakers.name: Josefine S
speakers.bio: 30-year-old frontend engineer based in Hamburg, Germany. Ready to take over the world by storm on good days, wondering when she will be exposed as the imposter she is on bad ones.

title: It's the Markup That Matters
abstract: Learn how the markup we write impacts not just the Document Object Model (DOM), but, indirectly, also the Accessibility Object Model (AOM), and how this impacts end users.

speakers.name: Hidde de Vries
speakers.bio: Hidde is a web developer and accessibility specialist who believes in the power of markup. As a freelancer, he helps governments, organisations and companies with fast, scalable and accessible front-end solutions for their end users.

title: Developing Beyond Code
abstract: Design is an important aspect of every product development process. Sometimes designers are left out of the development process after the design is handed to the engineering team and often end up lamenting about the designs not being implemented as intended. They understand the “why” and “who” of the product development and should be included in the process till delivery.  In this talk, I would discuss why design is important and should be adopted in product development, Ways designers can help improve products, Pitch Ideas to stakeholders, and also save the company money.

speakers.name: Victory Brown
speakers.bio: Victory Brown is a user experience designer with knowledge in user research, user interviews, storytelling, prototyping, wire-framing, and more. With a background in education, she has successfully transitioned into technology as a User Experience Designer,  open source advocate, and a member of the sustain UX working group. She loves talking about design, accessibility, and diversity.

title: This Box Will Change Your Life
abstract: Is the struggle of battling with margins, paddings and layout in front end development all too familiar? Understanding the CSS box model will change your life. By exploring this powerful and fundamental concept through a series of code examples and real-world examples, you'll feel empowered to tackle your next project with confidence. CSS doesn't have to be scary. This box will change your life.

speakers.name: Salma Alam-Naylor
speakers.bio: Salma — also known as whitep4nth3r — helps developers build stuff, learn things and love what they do. She's a teacher, musician, and an expert in web technologies, with a fierce mission to promote accessibility and inclusivity in technology on planet earth.

title: The Beauty of Being Stuck
abstract:
Being stuck is an uncomfortable feeling when developing. Over time, I've realized there's something beautiful about being stuck. It signifies the precipice of knowledge. Ultimately, I want to give early in career developers tools and support to get unstuck. Here's what I'd love to talk about:

- Everyone gets stuck from early devs to senior and beyond.
- Why getting stuck is beneficial. I'd like to do a little deep dive into the psychology of learning.
- What should you do when you get stuck. And how do you move on. I'd love to talk about this with a remote mindset.

speakers.name: Jonathan Yeong
speakers.bio: Jonathan Yeong is a Senior Developer at Shopify and a Rubyist at heart. In his spare time, Jonathan produces videos about all things programming and writes on dev.to and CodeNewbie Community about topics that matter to early-career developers.

title: When Deeds Speak, Words Mean Nothing
abstract:
"If you don't have a seat at the table, you're probably on the menu" The lack of diversity in tech persists and needs to be tackled from a different perspective. I'm reminded again of the following; "If they don't offer you a seat at the table, bring a folding chair." I want the talk to inspire underrepresented groups to not shy away from considering a career in tech. A talk that takes a historical and a global look at the achievements and contributions women and POC have and are making in tech.
How individuals with limited resources are helping to solve problems for their local communities.

speakers.name: Charlene Kuye
speakers.bio: Charlene considers herself an "accidental coder" — never in a million years did she think she'd be working in tech. But working towards becoming an instructor for Harvard's famous CS50 course was the catalyst for change she needed to enter the field. In 2020, she founded DCODED ACADEMY, an online hub dedicated to teaching and building a diverse community of UX/UI developers and designers who code.

title: How to Find a Mentor
abstract:
Your first few years as a software developer can be very challenging. There is so much to learn about coding and building a career in the technology industry. Doing it by yourself can be overwhelming. This is where mentors come in.

Most people have to find a mentor themselves. Most people, however, don't know how to find a mentor. What should you do? Where should you start?

We will cover the following concepts:
- What is mentorship?
- What to do before searching for a mentor
- Where to find mentors?
- How to ask someone to be your mentor
- How to work with a mentor once you have found one

speakers.name: Tanaka Mutakwa
speakers.bio: Tanaka is a technology leader who is driven to help software engineers have fulfilling careers. He works as the VP of Engineering at Names & Faces.

title: You’re Not an Imposter, You’re a Life-Long Learner
abstract: We talk about imposter Syndrome a lot in tech, but not as much in schools; students don't seem to often have imposter syndrome. That's because it comes from the expectations you hold for yourself. Students _know_ they're students and thus expect to be learning. We are always learning, but imposter syndrome seeks to tell us that we should already know better even when it's impossible to do so. This session will give you a toolbox to replace that thinking with a desire for opportunity rather than the pre-conception that allows a confidence killer to take root.

speakers.name: Pj Metz
speakers.bio: Pj is a former educator who now works as an Education Evangelist at GitLab. After teaching for 11 years, Pj made the transition into tech in May of 2021 after teaching himself to code during the summer and fall of the pandemic. He is a passionate public speaker and has spoken at a Microsoft conference as well as hosted several meetups and other events representing GitLab. You can catch him on Twitch building a website about poetry or building his next pop-star-based Twitter bot.

title: Art History is a Feature: Non-Dev Work as a Superpower
abstract:
This talk will explore how work and educational experience in non-dev fields, like art history, retail, or anything else really, can be a superpower in your dev career. I'd like audience to come away understanding the many way you can acquire the skills to be a successful dev. We'll explore topics like:
-Conducting a skills inventory & connecting those skills to your dev career 
-How to talk about your non-dev work in interviews & professional settings
-What to do when people don't get it

speakers.name: Tracey Berg-Fulton
speakers.bio: Tracey Berg-Fulton is a Software Engineer at Lumen Learning. Before learning to code in 2016, Tracey spent nearly a decade working in museums as a registrar & provenance researcher. She holds degrees in art and journalism from Otterbein, and a master's degree in art history from the University of Glasgow. In her spare time, Tracey competes in powerlifting, runs silly distances, and studies Gàidhlig. She shares her Pittsburgh home with her giant schnabrador, Walter, who is a very good boy.

title: How to Provide Value from Day One of Your Dev Career
abstract:
As a developer, you might think that the only way you can contribute to your team is through the lines of code that you produce. But in actuality, the job of a developer is significantly more sociotechnical than purely technical. And as you progress in your career, the less tangible ways to provide value become more important. Learn how you can do that from your very first day 🗓️

Situations we will cover:
- Documentation 📝
- Team Culture and Alignment ✔️
- Product Quality 💯
- Onboarding Experience 💻
- Peer Development 🤝

speakers.name: Thuy Doan
speakers.bio: Thuy Doan is a Canadian developer working at Prodigy Education. Before that, she was a business school graduate and a social media marketer, who once ran a blog and wrote the odd commercial here and there. She loves MMOs but retired in 2011 because she could not stop opening Gacha boxes. Her favorite game is Contra III and her favorite thing is a candid conversation.

title: From Contributor to Maintainer/Manager in Open Source
abstract: As contributors begin their journey into Open source, they gain new skills and experience that increase their capacity and impact on their careers. Most contributors even consider handling maintainer/management roles within the community they find themselves in. While contributors and managers are seen as problem solvers in a community, they both solve problems in different ways. In this session, we'll look at the difference between an individual contributor’s role and a manager's role in a community. We'll also discuss ways to transition and fit into a managerial role as a contributor.

speakers.name: Anita Ihuman
speakers.bio: Anita is a software developer, an author, and a speaker who enjoys teaching, sharing information through technical writing, learning, and engaging with open source communities.

title: Docs Are Everyone's Business
abstract:
2020 was the year we began showing our product docs the care they needed and made them inner sourced, because docs are everyone's business. 
Our goal was to make it easy for our teams and customers to use and love our cloud product internally, with the help of documentation. So, what did we learn, and how did we do it?
In this talk, Alex will take you through the then and now journey of how internal engineering product docs evolved and how the community and customers contribute to the changes and how you can do it too!

speakers.name: Alex Radu
speakers.bio:
Best known as lover of unicorns and all things magical, including data, design and code, Alex has been working at JPMC since 2016 and is now VP Product Adoption Lead for Public Cloud. She has just finished her MSc Computer Science at the University of Bath and in her work she combines content, data, communities and cloud. 
Personally, she is currently recovering from a crush on 80s music and glassblowing!

title: Babystepping Your Way to Becoming an Open Source Contributor
abstract:
People look for the perfect opportunity to start contributing to open source: an ideal match of languages and interests, something they are deeply knowledgeable about, their own idea. Frequently this won't be the case, but it's perfectly ok to contribute even if you're not the most respected expert in that field. Submit a pull request, make mistakes and... be ok with it!
Come learn how to slowly, but surely, start contributing: finding out things you care about and want to help grow, getting the confidence to submit an issue or a PR, stepping up to say "let me help you handle that, officially"!

speakers.name: Tulio Paschoalin Leao
speakers.bio: Tulio always wanted to be involved in open source, and all of a sudden he was a contributor, then the maintainer of a project, three projects, and a few organizations — who knows how many by the time this gets published!

title: How I Went From Tech Support to Developer
abstract:
My first job was for Nintendo of America, telling people how to connect their consoles up to a television. My talk covers how I started there and became a full-time developer, without a computer science degree, or an ivy-league pedigree, or a coding bootcamp.

The main talking points:

* discrimination in tech is real
* my story
* how I self-taught
 > focus on one topic
 > the truth about bootcamps
* Getting that first role
* knowing when to move on - how to change jobs
* burnout! on the dev team
* the current tech scene and the skills (I think!) that are the most valuable

speakers.name: Nočnica Fee
speakers.bio: Nočnica Fee is a developer advocate specializing in cloud applications, serverless computing, and containerization. She writes regularly for The New Stack and has been published in Information Age and Forbes. She blogs on dev.to, streams on Twitch at twitch.tv/serverlessmom, and spends her weekends caring for her dozens of houseplants.
